item.description: Opioid settlement payouts, groundwater wells, work-injury laws, colonial empire timelines, and objects launched into outer space.
item.content:encoded:
Opioid settlement payouts, groundwater wells, work-injury laws, colonial empire timelines, and objects launched into outer space.

Â 

ğŸ”„ Last month the Caselaw Access Project, initially featured in DIP 2018.11.07, announced that the full text of all 7 million state and federal cases it has collected â€” spanning 36 million pages â€” are now freely available in bulk. (Previously, bulk data were only available for select states.) Read more: Former director Adam Ziegler on the projectâ€™s past, present, and future. [h/t Derek M. Jones]

Â 

ğŸ‘‹ DIP+ members got a sneak peek of this editionâ€™s datasets on Monday, plus pointers to a few extra. Support the newsletter and your career by becoming a member.

Â 

Opioid settlement payouts. KFF Health News has been following the slew of legal settlements by companies accused of exacerbating the opioid crisis. Last week, they published an interactive and downloadable database of payouts to state and local governments so far (and expected in the future) from the largest national settlement, â€œa $26 billion deal with four companies that will be paid out over nearly two decades.â€ The data, gathered from the court-appointed firm administering the settlement, include overall numbers for 48 states and DC, plus locality-level data for 35 states. (Los Angeles County, for instance, received $47 million in 2022 and 2023, with another $210 million expected in years to come.) Learn more: A webinar scheduled for tomorrow, in which reporter Aneri Pattani â€œwill discuss the data and how it can help you launch into coverage of the historic opioid settlement story.â€

Â 

Groundwater wells. Despite the infrastructural importance of groundwater wells, â€œa unified database collecting and standardizing information on the characteristics and locations of these wells across the United States has been lacking,â€ Chung-Yi Lin et al. write. â€œTo bridge this gap, we have created a comprehensive database of groundwater well records collected from state and federal agencies.â€ Their United States Groundwater Well Database contains ~14 million records, each indicating a well equipped for monitoring or extracting water. Where available, each row lists the wellâ€™s coordinates, county, aquifer, watershed, depth, capacity, water use category, water potability, and more. [h/t Derek M. Jones]

Â 

Work-injury laws. Nate Breznau and Felix Lanverâ€™s Global Work-Injury Policy Database tracks the history of work-injury laws (also known as workersâ€™ compensation laws) in 186 â€œindependent nation states.â€ For each, the database lists the year of its first such law, the year a law first provided insurance for work-related injuries, the type of program it established, and more. It also incorporates data on current lawsâ€™ coverage and payment rates from Kenneth Nelson et al.â€™s Social Insurance Entitlements dataset.

Â 

Colonial empire timelines. The Colonial Dates Dataset, compiled by political scientist Bastian Becker, â€œaggregates information on the reach and duration of European colonial empires from renowned secondary sources.â€ Producing the dataset from its four main sources â€œis largely automated, relying on predefined coding rules.â€ The dataset indicates the first and last years each contemporary country was colonized, disaggregated by eight colonizing countries (Belgium, Britain, France, Germany, Italy, Netherlands, Portugal, and Spain). [h/t Erik Gahner Larsen]

Â 

Things flung spaceward. The UNâ€™s Office for Outer Space Affairs maintains an Online Index of Objects Launched into Outer Space, based on a similarly-named register, itself mandated by a similarly-named convention, which went into force in 1976. Presented as an HTML table, the index lists 17,000+ satellites, spacecraft, probes, and other objectsâ€™ names, launching countries, statuses, launch dates, and more. As seen in: Our World In Dataâ€™s chart of the annual number of objects launched. [h/t Chartr]

Â

item.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2024.04.03 edition
item.description: Power outages, European Parliament activity, candid animals, LLM data provenance, and deaths in plague-era London.
item.content:encoded:
Power outages, European Parliament activity, candid animals, LLM data provenance, and deaths in plague-era London.

Â 

ğŸ”„ Earlier this year, the USDA released the 2022 edition of its Census of Agriculture, initially featured in DIP 2015.12.23. National, state, and county data are available to download. Data for Puerto Rico are coming in July, and for the rest of US territories in 2025. [h/t Jasmine Mithani]

Â 

ğŸ‘‹ DIP+ members got a sneak peek of this editionâ€™s datasets on Monday, plus pointers to a few extra. Support the newsletter and your career by becoming a member.

Â 

Power outages. Christa Brelsford et al. have compiled a county-level estimates of the number of US customers experiencing power outages at 15-minute intervals from 2014 to 2023. The records come from Oak Ridge National Laboratoryâ€™s restricted-access Environment for Analysis of Geo-Located Energy Information, a â€œplatform created to monitor electric utility customer outages from data gathered from public sources.â€ The dataâ€™s coverage has increased over time; by 2022, it represented 92% of customers in the 50 states, DC, and Puerto Rico. â€œThe remaining 8% of customers belong to utilities which do not report outage information publicly in near-real time in a format that is currently accessible to EAGLE-I parsers,â€ the authors write. â€œThese are most typically small, rural, municipal utilities which lack robust information technology infrastructure.â€

Â 

European Parliament activity. Parltrack keeps tabs on 4,000+ active and prior members of the European Parliament, 23,000+ policy dossiers, 39,000+ votes, and much more. The project, launched in 2011, scrapes data from various official websites and links it together â€” so that you can see, for example, any given memberâ€™s dossiers, committee roles, and activities such as plenary speeches and proposed legislative amendments. Its bulk datasets are updated daily and include details beyond what the online interfaces offer. [h/t Stefan Marsiske]

Â 

Candid animals. The Labeled Information Library of Alexandria data repository is â€œintended as a resource for both machine learning (ML) researchers and those that want to harness ML for biology and conservation.â€ Its datasets include millions of images, mostly captured by motion-triggered cameras. Its North American Camera Trap Images dataset, for instance, â€œcontains 3.7M camera trap images from five locations across the United States, with labels for 28 animal categories, primarily at the species level.â€ Read more: â€œMachine learning to classify animal species in camera trap images: Applications in ecology.â€ [h/t Corin Faife]

Â 

LLM data provenance. The Data Provenance Initiative â€œis a multi-disciplinary volunteer effort to improve transparency, documentation, and responsible use of training datasets for AI.â€ Its first release, the Data Provenance Collection, catalogs dozens of corpora used for fine-tuning large language models, as well as their component datasetsâ€™ names, task categories, known sources, licensing, various text metrics, and more. Related: Yang Liu et al.â€™s â€œDatasets for Large Language Models: A Comprehensive Survey,â€ accompanied by semi-structured descriptions of hundreds of training and evaluation datasets. [h/t u/cavedave]

Â 

Deaths in plague-era London. Death by Numbers, also known as the Bills of Mortality Project, aims to transcribe ~8,000 official weekly tallies of deaths in London published in the 1600s and 1700s. Initially focused on plague deaths, the reports expanded to â€œdozens of other causes of death, such as childbirth, measles, syphilis, and suicide, ensuring their continued publication for decades after the final outbreak of plague in England.â€ The projectâ€™s data are available to browse online, to download, and via API. [h/t Derek M. Jones + Cody Winchester]

Â

item.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2024.03.27 edition
item.description: Institutional investments, HDI, extrajudicial killings in Bangladesh, agri-environmental policies, and Rolling Stoneâ€™s album rankings.
item.content:encoded:
Institutional investments, HDI, extrajudicial killings in Bangladesh, agri-environmental policies, and Rolling Stoneâ€™s album rankings.

Â 

ğŸ“¬ ReaderÂ Erin Wilson has built a range of visualizations and analyses based on the Netflix viewership data featured in DIP 2023.12.20 â€¦ and a video walking you through it. (Have you published something with data you found via Data Is Plural?Â Click here to let me know.)

Â 

ğŸ‘‹ DIP+ members got a sneak peek of this editionâ€™s datasets on Monday. Support the newsletter and your career by becoming a member.

Â 

Institutional investments. If youâ€™re an institutional investor with US operations and managing at least $100 million in publicly traded securities, the Securities and Exchange Commission requires you to file Form 13F each quarter. (The biggest filers â€” such as Vanguard, BlackRock, and State Street â€” have trillions of dollars invested.) These filings, available to download going back to mid-2013, detail each investorâ€™s long positions for each security: their number of shares, market value, security type, issuer name, CUSIP code, and more. As seen in: Michigan teenager Anonyo Noorâ€™s wallstreetlocal.com, which aggregates the data, matches it to additional information, and provides a search interface.

Â 

Human development, indexed. Perhaps the best-known metric of its kind, the United Nationsâ€™ Human Development Index combines statistics on life expectancy, income per capita, and years of schooling into a single number for each country-year. The UN provides downloads and an API for all annual HDI ratings and sub-components for 1990 to 2022. Those resources also feature data from related indices, such as the Inequality-adjusted Human Development Index, Gender Development Index, and Gender Inequality Index. [h/t Michael A. Rice]

Â 

Extrajudicial killings in Bangladesh. Between 2009 and 2022, â€œBangladeshâ€™s security forces killed at least 2,597 people in apparent extrajudicial executions, custodial torture, and by firing bullets at protesters,â€ according to Nazmul Ahasanâ€™s analysis for Netra News, building on data â€œcompiled by Bangladeshi human rights defenders and collated by the Australia-based Capital Punishment Justice Project.â€ Ahasan and colleagues â€œindependently verified more than 98% of the cases in the dataset using press reports and subsequently updated any incomplete data.â€ The records are available as a table in the article and as a JSON file. Each entry includes the victimâ€™s name (if known), incident date, description, location, agencies involved, purported justification, and news source. As seen in: The 2024 Sigma Awards.

Â 

Agri-environmental policies. David Wuepper et al. have constructed a dataset of 6,000+ policies between 1960 and 2022 â€œat the intersection of agriculture and the environment, implemented not only by national entities but also by subnational and supranational entities, covering different instruments (for example, regulations, frameworks, payment programmes) and topics,â€ such as the US Safe Drinking Water Act, the Bavarian Forestry Law, and Tanzaniaâ€™s 2009 Wildlife Conservation Act. Each entry lists the policyâ€™s country, title, type, keywords, year implemented, description, and other details.

Â 

Rolling Stoneâ€™s album rankings. A new visual essay from The Pudding compares Rolling Stoneâ€™s â€œ500 Greatest Albums of All Timeâ€ lists from 2003, 2012, and 2020. A methodology note says the project began with a spreadsheet by Chris Eckert and eventually led the authors to develop a dataset of their own. Theirs lists every album in the rankings â€” its name, genre, release year, 2003/2012/2020 rank, the artistâ€™s name, birth year, gender, and more â€” plus each yearâ€™s voters. [h/t Jason Kottke]

Â

item.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2024.03.20 edition
item.description: Human trafficking, real-world vehicle emissions, state legislators, Meta Oversight Board decisions, and aviation waypoints.
item.content:encoded:
Human trafficking, real-world vehicle emissions, state legislators, Meta Oversight Board decisions, and aviation waypoints.

Â 

ğŸ“¬ Reader Aditya Dahiya has built a showcase of his Data Is Pluralâ€“inspired visualizations. â€œHere, youâ€™ll find open-source code detailing every step, from data acquisition to final rendering,â€ Aditya writes. (Have you published something with data you found via Data Is Plural?Â Click here to let me know.)

Â 

Human trafficking. The Counter-Trafficking Data Collaborativeâ€™s Global Synthetic Dataset uses differential privacy techniques to represent â€œover 206,000 victims and survivors of trafficking identified across 190 countries and territories from 2002 to 2022.â€ The approach, developed in partnership with Microsoft Research, converts anonymized case records into â€œa new dataset in which records do not correspond to actual individuals, but which preserves the structure and statistics (i.e., utility) of the original data.â€ Each row indicates a (synthetic) individualâ€™s gender, age group, citizenship, country of exploitation, duration of reported trafficking, traffickersâ€™ means of control, types of exploitation, and the year the collaborativeâ€™s partners registered the case. Related: The collaborativeâ€™s Global Victim-Perpetrator Synthetic Dataset, which takes a similar approach to relationships between victims and perpetrators. [h/t Mariana Moreira + Lorraine Wong]

Â 

Real-world vehicle emissions. On Monday, the European Commission published its first report analyzing the real-world CO2 emissions of cars and vans, based on fuel consumption monitoring devices that the EU now requires. The report uses data received from 600,000+ vehicles. That sample is available to download, along with metrics aggregated by manufacturer and fuel type: average fuel consumption, emissions, and comparisons to standardized test results. Related: Data on millions of EU car registrations (and van registrations), including each vehicleâ€™s fuel economy and emissions ratings. Previously: FuelEconomy.gov (DIP 2017.04.12), with data on decades of car models. [h/t Jan Willem Tulp + Xan Gregg]

Â 

State legislators. Nicholas Carnes and Eric Hansenâ€™s 2023-4 State Legislators Dataset features â€œbiographical information about state lawmakers who held office in 2023 and 2024 compiled from legislative and campaign websites and other online sources.â€ The dataset spans all 50 states and includes 7,300+ lawmakers. â€œThe projectâ€™s principal aim was to record the current or most recent main occupation (outside of elected office) held by each member,â€ the authors write, â€œbut the dataset also includes information about a wide range of characteristics including race, gender, and education.â€ A version for 2021â€“22 is also available. Previously: State legislator financial disclosures (DIP 2017.12.13) and ideology scores (DIP 2020.01.01). [h/t Derek Willis]

Â 

Meta Oversight Board decisions. Metaâ€™s independent Oversight Board reviews a selection of the companyâ€™s content-moderation decisions and has the power to overturn them. The board publishes its rulings online, as does Meta itself; neither, however, provides a download link. But Information Is Beautiful has compiled a spreadsheet of the boardâ€™s 80+ decisions through early February, supporting a visualization of the casesâ€™ topics and outcomes over time. [h/t Data Science Community Newsletter]

Â 

Aviation waypoints. For his recent exploration of the FAAâ€™s aviation maps, Beautiful Public Dataâ€™s Jon Keegan has turned the agencyâ€™s list of 67,000+ navigation waypoints into a downloadable dataset. â€œOften these waypoint names will reflect the culture, food or sports teams of the city they are near,â€ Keegan writes. â€œOff the coast of New England, there is LBSTA and WHALE. Bostonâ€™s sports legacy gave us BOSOX, BRUWN, CELTS, PATSS, FENWY, ORRRR and BORQE. Salem has WITCH, and Plymouth has PLGRM.â€

Â

item.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2024.03.13 edition
item.description: Humanitarian emergency mapping, materials and their properties, EU infringements, NYC council members, and counting fish.
item.content:encoded:
Humanitarian emergency mapping, materials and their properties, EU infringements, NYC council members, and counting fish.

Â 

ğŸ“¬ ReaderÂ Jack T. has built an interactive map of the data on â€œeducational gag ordersâ€ compiled by PEN America, featured in DIPÂ 2022.08.24. (Have you published something with data you found via Data Is Plural?Â Click here to let me know.)

Â 

ğŸ‘‹ DIP+ members got a sneak peek of this editionâ€™s datasets yesterday, received dispatches from last weekâ€™s NICAR conference, and get ongoing access to a semantic-search-bot for the DIP archives. Support the newsletter and your career by signing up.

Â 

Humanitarian emergency mapping. The United Nations Satellite Centre (UNOSAT) provides a range of services to UN agencies and the general public, including downloadable maps, data, and analyses produced â€œin response to humanitarian emergencies related to disasters, complex emergencies and conflict situations.â€ Those currently available include assessments of flood impacts in Libya, landslides in the Republic of the Congo, and building damage in the Gaza Strip. The latter identifies structures that satellite imagery suggests have been damaged; the data indicate each buildingâ€™s location and damage level, plus an assessment confidence and notes. Assessments for prior humanitarian emergencies can be found by adjusting the listing pageâ€™s filters, and also via UNOSATâ€™s contributions to the Humanitarian Data Exchange. [h/t Allison Martell]

Â 

Materials and their properties. The Materials Project, led by scientists at Lawrence Berkeley National Lab, â€œis a multi-institution, multi-national effort to compute the properties of all inorganic materialsâ€ with the â€œultimate goalâ€ being â€œto drastically reduce the time needed to invent new materials.â€ Its online explorer and API currently provide information about 150,000+ materials. You can search by component elements, formula, thermodynamics, structural properties, magnetism, elasticity, and many other characteristics.

Â 

EU infringements. The European Commission publishes a searchable and downloadable database of all its decisions regarding national infringements of EU regulations, decisions, and directives. It currently contains 58,000+ decisions in 24,000+ cases, going back to the late 1980s. (To download the full database, conduct a blank search and then click the â€œExport to Excelâ€ link.) Each entry lists a decision type and date, case identifier, country, policy area, and more. Recent examples include the Commissionâ€™s decisions to refer Ireland to court for failing to protect its peat bogs and Italy for noncompliance with a wastewater treatment directive. [h/t Maximilian Haag et al.]

Â 

NYC council members. Maximum New York has published a biographical dataset of people elected to the New York City Council. For each member since 1998 (plus some before that), it lists their name, district, borough, political party, date of birth, undergraduate/graduate universities and fields of study, whether they ever served on a community board, prior employer, and more. Related: DataMadeâ€™s Chicago Councilmatic lists all members, bills, votes, and meetings, and is also available as structured data. [h/t Vikram Oberoi + Forest Gregg]

Â 

Counting fish. The University of Washingtonâ€™s Columbia Basin Research provides (among other data) daily, species-level counts of adult salmon and trout passing through more than a dozen sites in the Pacific Northwest. CalFish publishes fish counts and population estimates for the Upper Sacramento River Basin, which â€œcontains much of Californiaâ€™s salmon and steelhead populations.â€ Similar resources include those available from Alaska, Oregon, and the Yakama Nation. [h/t Dan Brady]

Â

item.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2024.03.06 edition
item.description: Global military spending, fatal police pursuits, price-fixing cartels, real-time airport disruptions, and pinball machines.
item.content:encoded:
Global military spending, fatal police pursuits, price-fixing cartels, real-time airport disruptions, and pinball machines.

Â 

ğŸ“¬ ReaderÂ Nick Hillmanâ€™sÂ research teamÂ at the University of Wisconsin uses data from the federal governmentâ€™s DailyÂ TreasuryÂ Statements (DIPÂ 2023.04.05) toÂ track the estimated volume of student loan paymentsÂ over time. Although Nick learned about that data via non-DIP sources, the project is exactly the type I like to feature in these notes. (Have you published something with data you found via DIP?Â Click here to let me know.)

Â 

ğŸ‘‹ DIP+ members got a sneak peek of this weekâ€™s datasets on Monday, and get ongoing access to a semantic-search-bot for the DIP archives. Iâ€™ve also posted a roundup of downloadable data published by the Sigma Awardsâ€™ shortlisted projects and pointers to upcoming data-related events. Support the newsletter and your career by signing up; memberships are just $7/month or $60/year.

Â 

Global military spending. How much money has each country spent, each year, on its military? Different datasets have different answers, cover different timeframes, and use different methodologies. Miriam Barnum et al.â€™s Global Military Spending Dataset attempts to bring them together. By uniting â€œ76 variables from 9 dataset collection projects,â€ the authors write, â€œwe provide the most comprehensive and complete set of published datasets on military spending ever assembled.â€ Each of the variables represents one source/methodology, and each observation is a country-year. â€œDisagreement on the actual expenditure value for a given country-year is common, even between datasets produced by the same project,â€ they find. Previously: The Stockholm International Peace Research Instituteâ€™s Military Expenditure Database (DIP 2017.03.29), one of the sources.

Â 

Fatal police pursuits. Reporters at the San Francisco Chronicle have compiled a national dataset of 3,300+ deaths in police car chases in 2017â€“2022. To build it, they used information from the federal governmentâ€™s Fatality Analysis Reporting System (DIP 2016.08.31), research organizations, news reports, lawsuits, and public records requests. For each death, the dataset indicates the personâ€™s name, age, gender, race, and connection to the pursuit (driver, passenger, bystander, officer). It also includes the incidentâ€™s date, location, reason given for the pursuit, and main law enforcement agency involved. Read more: â€œFast and Fatal,â€ the Chronicleâ€™s investigation based on the dataset. [h/t Susie Neilson]

Â 

Price-fixing cartels. Industrial economist John M. Connor has constructed the Private International Cartels dataset, â€œwhich the author believes to be the largest collection of legal-economic information on contemporary price-fixing cartels.â€ It spans three decades (1990â€“2019) and covers 1,500+ suspected or convicted cartels, including 1,100+ that â€œhave been deemed guilty of price fixing by one or more antitrust authority.â€ It also links those cartels to tens of thousands of companies and to 2,000+ individuals indicted or punished for their involvement. The datasetâ€™s variables include information about cartel geography, industry, market share, overcharges, penalties, and much more.

Â 

Real-time airport disruptions. The Federal Aviation Administrationâ€™s National Airspace System Status dashboard provides real-time listings of delays and closures at US airports. For each disruption, it indicates the type of problem, reason, current average delay times, and more. A minimal API linked from the site provides the information as an XML-formatted file. Read more: Ruihai Youngblood describes his experience helping to redesign the dashboard. [h/t Jason Scott]

Â 

Pinball machines. The Open Pinball Database provides a searchable inventory and API of ~2,000 pinball machines and 120+ manufacturers. Details include each machineâ€™s name, manufacture date, mechanism type, display type, player count, and more. Related: Pinball Mapâ€™s crowdsourced global map and API of the locations of installed pinball machines. [h/t Jeremy Herrman + technophiliac]

Â

item.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2024.02.28 edition
item.description: Climate funding, federal laws since 1789, TSA complaint counts, high-school financial education, and Mr. Trash Wheel.
item.content:encoded:
Climate funding, federal laws since 1789, TSA complaint counts, high-school financial education, and Mr. Trash Wheel.

Â 

Â 

Data Is Plural sends its heartfelt condolences to the friends and family of Fazil Khan, a young and talented data journalist whose work was recently featured here. Fazil died in New York City on Friday, when his apartment building caught fire. The Columbia Journalism School is hosting an online and in-person memorial service today at 6pm EST.

Â 

Â 

Climate funding. To develop its â€œGlobal Landscape of Climate Finance 2023â€ report, the Climate Policy Initiative gathered data on grants, loans, equity and other types of â€œprimary financing in real economy sectors that reduce greenhouse gas emissions and build climate resilience.â€ The report, published in November, identified ~$1.3 trillion in such financing globally in 2021â€“2022. A spreadsheet provided alongside it indicates the estimated amount by year, region, sector, focus on mitigation vs. adaptation, type of financial instrument, funder sector (public vs. private), and funder type (development bank, corporation, institutional investors, etc.). Reports from earlier years include downloadable data for 2019â€“2020 and 2017â€“2018. Previously: National climate funds (DIP 2022.02.09) and climate finance projects (DIP 2023.06.14).

Â 

Federal laws since 1789. Political scientist and â€œrecovering lawyerâ€ Brian Libgober has compiled a â€œcomprehensive dataset of U.S. federal laws,â€ covering 49,000+ legislative enactments from 1789 to 2022. Such a dataset has been elusive, Libgober notes, in part â€œbecause such laws have been enacted over hundreds of years, resulting in a complicated patchwork of documents published in numerous and inconsistent formats.â€ His solution combines three key sources: â€œthe oldest meta data for the U.S. Statutes at Large disseminated via HeinOnline, similar and more recent meta data through the Governmental Printing Office, and finally the last six years of law-making as described by the National Archivesâ€™ website.â€ The dataset lists each lawâ€™s title, legislative session, date of passage, source/citation identifiers, and more.

Â 

TSA complaint counts. The Transportation Security Administration publishes semi-regular reports on the complaints it receives, aggregated by month, airport, category, and subcategory. Unfortunately, the agency only publishes those reports as PDFs, rather than structured data files. So volunteers and I at the Data Liberation Project have built a data pipeline to convert those PDFs into tidy CSV files, currently covering complaints to TSA at 440+ airports (and additional complaints not specifying any airport) from January 2015 to January 2024. Read more: The Data Liberation Projectâ€™s latest newsletter dispatch.

Â 

High-school financial education. In a recent paper, economists Allison Oldham Luedtke and Carly Urban introduce a dataset of 19,000+ high-school classes that teach financial literacy, manually collected from thousands of online course catalogs. Each row provides details about the school (e.g., name, location, enrollment) and course, including its title, description, duration, requirement status, and whether financial literacy was the main focus or smaller component. An auxiliary dataset indicates, annually for 1970â€“2024, which states required such coursework for high school graduation.

Â 

Trash interceptors. Mr. Trash Wheel is one of four â€œsemi-autonomous trash interceptorsâ€ pulling garbage out of the Baltimore Harbor. The partnership behind the effort publishes spreadsheets of each contraptionâ€™s collection history. For each dumpster filled since May 2014, they list the date, weight and volume of trash, and estimated number of plastic bottles, cigarette butts, and other types of items extracted. [h/t Cody Winchester]

Â

item.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2024.02.21 edition
item.description: Self-driving stats, US wetlands, SF overdose deaths, Spainâ€™s political primaries, and Scottâ€™s SMS spam.
item.content:encoded:
Self-driving stats, US wetlands, SF overdose deaths, Spainâ€™s political primaries, and Scottâ€™s SMS spam.

Â 

ğŸ“¬ Reader Aleksandra Chirkina has explored the relationship between self-claimed expertise and coffee preferences in the data from James Hoffmanâ€™s Great American Coffee Taste Test (featured in DIP 2023.11.15). Have you published something with data you found via DIP? Click here to let me know.

Â 

ğŸ‘‹ DIP+ members got a sneak peek of this weekâ€™s datasets on Monday, links to additional datasets too niche for the newsletter, and a mini-analysis of Hobbesâ€™ appearances in the Visual Language Research Corpus. We also chatted about data-intensive programs that run entirely browser-side and changes to Census surveysâ€™ questions about gender. Come join us! Memberships are just $7/month or $60/year.

Â 

Self-driving stats. Companies wanting to test or deploy self-driving cars on Californiaâ€™s public roads must receive a permit from the state DMVâ€™s Autonomous Vehicles Program. As part of the requirements, these companies must â€œsubmit annual reports to share how often their vehicles disengaged from autonomous mode during tests (whether because of technology failure or situations requiring the test driver/operator to take manual control of the vehicle to operate safely).â€ These disengagement reports indicate each vehicleâ€™s company, permit number, VIN, monthly miles driven, and annual disengagements â€” including vehicles with none. And for each disengagement, the reports list the vehicle, date, disengagement initiator (vehicle, test driver, remote operator, or passenger), type of location, and a brief summary. [h/t Chartr]

Â 

US wetlands. The National Wetlands Inventory, maintained by the US Fish and Wildlife Service, provides interactive maps and bulk data containing â€œgeospatially referenced information on the status, extent, characteristics and functions of wetland, riparian, deepwater, and related aquatic habitats.â€ With contributions from 160+ organizations, coordinated through a dedicated national standard, the inventory represents â€œmore than 35 million wetland and deepwater features,â€ and continues to receive updates. As seen in: DIP reader Simon Greenhill and coauthorsâ€™ paper, dataset, explainer video, and map using machine learning to predict wetland and river protections under the Clean Water Act.

Â 

SF overdose deaths. Last year, 813 people died from accidental drug overdoses in San Francisco, according to the latest figures from the cityâ€™s Office of the Chief Medical Examiner. Thatâ€™s the highest annual total on record, per the San Francisco Chronicleâ€™s overdose data tracker, which combines data from the medical examinerâ€™s reports with information from other city agencies, such as overdose reversals by EMS responders administering naloxone and calls handled by the Street Overdose Response Team. As seen in: The Chronicle data teamâ€™s latest newsletter.

Â 

Spainâ€™s political primaries. Oscar BarberÃ  et al. have compiled a dataset of the outcomes of 361 primary contests in Spain since 1991, â€œbased on information provided by political parties at the time of the event through their websites, press releases, and journalistic reports.â€ It includes primaries to determine candidates for regional, national, and EU elections, as well as for party leadership. For each contest, it lists the party, territory, year, type of post, number of competitors, turnout, incumbentâ€™s outcome, winnerâ€™s percentage, and more.

Â 

Scottâ€™s SMS spam. In late September 2022, Scott Lee Chua began preserving every SMS he received, motivated by the recent passage of the Philippine SIM Registration Act. By early February 2024, heâ€™d amassed 3,324 messages, which he has grouped into five categories and charted: spam (13% of all messages), one-time passwords (12%), marketing (10%), government notices (1%), and â€œmessages I both expect and welcomeâ€ (63%). Heâ€™s also published a partially-redacted dataset of each messageâ€™s time received, time read, sender, text, and category.

item.content:encoded:
State trust lands, household composition, comics deconstructed, nursing home prices, and twisty roads.

Â 

ğŸ‘‹ Over its eight years and 360+ editions, Data Is Pluralâ€™s newsletter and archives have been freely accessible â€”Â just like the datasets DIP features. I have no plans to change that. Occasionally, however, Iâ€™ve wondered what a â€œpremiumâ€ membership might look like. What could DIP offer to subscribers who wanted to dive deeper, to engage beyond the tidy boundaries of a newsletter? To that end: Introducing DIP+, Data Is Pluralâ€™s new membership program. For $60/year youâ€™ll get access to a Discord-hosted community, featuring bonus material, lively discussions with fellow data-spelunkers, job boards, and more. Thereâ€™s a 14-day free trial, so you can test it out first. Click here for details and to register. And feel free reply to this email with any questions or feedback.

Â 

State trust lands. â€œState trust lands just might be one of the best-kept public secrets in America,â€ according to Grist, which published a data-driven investigation on the topic last week. These lands â€” expropriated from Indigenous nations and managed by state governments for profit â€” â€œexist in 21 Western and Midwestern states, totaling more than 500 million surface and subsurface acres.â€ Gristâ€™s inquiry focuses on those benefiting land-grant universities, the subject of a related High Country News investigation (DIP 2020.06.24). Using state property records and Forest Service data digitized from historical cession maps, Grist identified â€œmore than 8.2 million acres of state trust parcels taken from 123 tribes, bands, and communitiesâ€ that fund 14 such institutions. Their public data describe these 41,000+ pieces of land: each parcelâ€™s size and location, rights type, land use, benefiting university, associated tribes, and cession details. [h/t Rachel Glickhouse]

Â 

Household composition. Juan Galeano et al.â€™s CORESIDENCE database provides 146 indicators of household arrangements in 156 countries and ~4,000 regions, spanning the years 1964 to 2021. The indicators range in specificity, from average household size to, e.g., the average number of non-relatives in 3-person households. They also include gender breakdowns, such as the proportion of 5-person households among female-headed households. The metrics are calculated using â€œglobal-scale individual microdata from four main repositories and national household surveys, encompassing over 150 million individual records representing more than 98% of the worldâ€™s population.â€

Â 

Comics, deconstructed. The Tilburg Universityâ€“based Visual Language Lab, led by comics scholar Neil Cohn, studies â€œall aspects of visual language, from the structure of individual drawings, emoji, or cartoons, to how we make meaning out of sequences of images like in comics.â€ The labâ€™s Visual Language Research Corpus provides detailed annotations of tens of thousands of panels in 300+ comic books and graphic novels (plus every Calvin & Hobbes strip). The datasetâ€™s sources include material from multiple continents, time periods, and genres. The annotations examine â€œattentional framing structure and filmic shot scale, the situational changes across panels, page layouts, multimodality, visual morphology, and path structure,â€ among other characteristics. [h/t Cameron Yick]

Â 

Nursing home prices. Between December 2020 and March 2022, SeniorLiving.org researchers â€œattempted to contact 7,221 US senior facilities by telephone to obtain availability and service pricing.â€ The team got at least some pricing data for 3,000+ of the facilities. The results, available from SeniorLivingâ€™s data portal, provide information about each provider, the teamâ€™s call attempts, and the average monthly price for five types of housing and care: skilled nursing with a private room, skilled nursing with a shared room, assisted living, independent living, and care tailored for people with Alzheimerâ€™s disease and dementia. Related: The Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Servicesâ€™ Skilled Nursing Facility Cost Report datasets, which contain annual metrics on finances, staffing, and care provided. [h/t Corie Wagner]

Â 

Twisty roads. Curvature uses OpenStreetMap data to map the worldâ€™s curviest roads. Built by motorcyclist and software developer Adam Franco, the open-source project â€œworks by looking at the geometry of every road segment and adding up how much length of the road is sharp corners, broad sweeping curves, and straight areas.â€ Franco also provides a more detailed explanation, as well as data files scoring each road and curve segment. [h/t Giuseppe Sollazzo]

item.content:encoded:
Local election results, anti-Black killings in the mid-century South, US travel behavior, space X-rays, and amateur archaeological finds.

Â 

Local election results. Justin de Benedictis-Kessner et al. have compiled a dataset of 77,000+ (distinct) candidates across 57,000+ US elections for mayor, city council, school board, county executive, county legislature, sheriff, and prosecutor. It is, they write, â€œthe most comprehensive publicly-available source of information on local elections across the entire country.â€ It includes â€œmost medium and large cities and countiesâ€ and spans 1989 to 2021. The authors combined data from pre-existing databases, state election websites, and newspaper archives. They also â€œworked with a team of research assistants who coded results from thousands of local elections based on city and county websites.â€ For each candidacy, the core table indicates the electionâ€™s jurisdiction, office, and timing, plus the candidateâ€™s name, incumbency status, party, estimated demographics, votes won, and more.

Â 

Mid-century anti-Black killings. The Burnham-Nobles Archive at the Northeastern University School of Law is â€œdedicated to identifying, classifying, and providing factual information and documentation about anti-Black killings in the mid-century South.â€ The current version focuses on 11 southern states during 1930â€“1954. Developed by political scientist Melissa Nobles and law professor Margaret Burnham, the long-running project has gathered 12,000+ news articles, death certificates, federal agency records, and other sources. It documents 900+ incidents and 950+ victims, as well as alleged perpetrators and judicial outcomes. The archive provides an interactive map, record search (including by person, incident, and document), and downloads. Previously: Beck/Tolnay and Seguin/Rigbyâ€™s data on lynching victims (DIP 2021.06.02). [h/t Jasmine Mithani]

Â 

US travel behavior. Fielded every five to eight years since 1968, the Federal Highway Administrationâ€™s National Household Travel Survey â€œis the authoritative source on the travel behavior of the American public.â€ The questionnaire asks respondents to inventory all of their householdâ€™s trips taken during a 24-hour period. The most recent survey, for 2022, includes ~31,000 trips by ~17,000 people in ~8,000 households. It indicates each tripâ€™s duration, vehicle details, motivation, parking costs, traveler demographics, and much more. The FHA provides downloads of the anonymized data, as well as user guides and technical notes. As seen in: â€œThe school bus is disappearing. Welcome to the era of the school pickup line,â€ by the Washington Postâ€™s Andrew Van Dam.

Â 

Space X-rays. eROSITA is a wide-field X-ray telescope â€œcapable of delivering deep, sharp images over very large areas of the sky,â€ helping researchers â€œto study the large-scale structure of the universe.â€ The telescope launched into orbit in 2019 as a collaboration between Russia and Germany, with data rights split between the countries. In February 2022, following Russiaâ€™s invasion of Ukraine, Germanyâ€™s Max Planck Institute suspended eROSITAâ€™s operations. Data processing continued, however, and last week the institute published its first data release. It contains the first six months of results for the hemisphere assigned to Germany, and is â€œthe largest X-ray catalogue ever published.â€

Â 

Amateur archaeological finds. The British Museumâ€™s Portable Antiquities Scheme â€œrecords archaeological finds discovered by the public,â€ assisted by a network of national and local partners. Its database contains 1.1 million records describing 1.7 million objects. â€œAll have been found by everyday people by chance, most through metal detecting.â€ The most common finds: coins (~500,000 records), buckles (~58,000), and brooches (~52,000). Search results are available in JSON, XML, and other structured formats. [h/t Maev Kennedy + Walt Hickey]
